description: From Middle French inmarcessible (1482), later immarcescible (“that does not shrivel" or "that does not perish”), from Latin immarcescibilis (“unfading”).

adjectives.description: immarcescible (comparative more immarcescible, superlative most immarcescible)

entries.meaning: (rare) Permanent, enduring; that does not perish.
examples: I did not think to see them once again, / For what could bring into an old woman's dream / Canova's immarcescible marble lovers?
